newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Australia cotton headed for new record - ABARE.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Australia cotton headed for new record - ABARE.

text.p: Australia's 1996/97 lint (cotton) production is forecast to set a new record of 2.6 million bales, or 582,000 tonnes, the official commodities forecasting agency the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE) said in its Australian Crop Report.
This would surpass the previous record of 2.2 million 500 lb bales produced in 1991/92, ABARE said.

"Bountiful supplies of irrigation water in most regions and higher returns for irrigated cotton relative to other crops are expected to result in increases in plantings of irrigated cotton of 108,000 ha in 1996/97," ABARE said.
Despite a 32,000 ha decline in dryland plantings, the total area planted to cotton in 1996/97 is forecast to reach a record 380,000 ha.
ABARE said that good August and September rains had created good prospects for summer crops in Queensland and New South Wales (NSW).

Cotton was the most profitable dryland crop despite the forecast decline in cotton prices in 1996/97. It was also by far the most profitable irrigated crop and farmers would be planting maximum cotton areas in 1996/97, ABARE said.

Falling cereal prices were forecast to reduce Australia's total sorghum plantings to 482,000 ha in 1996/97, down 26 percent on the previous year. Forecast sorghum production at almost 1.1 million tonnes is down by almost half a million tonnes from the previous season.
Sunflower and soybean plantings are expected to increase significantly in response to favourable prices, gross margins and excellent pre-planting rains during spring, ABARE said.

Total sunflower plantings are forecast to more than double to 158,000 ha. Production of sunflowers and soybeans is expected to increase by 75 percent and 18 percent respectively to 152,000 tonnes and 86,000 tonnes, ABARE said.
Rice plantings are forecast to also reach a new record, of 155,000 ha in 1996/97, 6,000 ha more than in 1995/96.

Rice production in 1996/97 is expected to be a 1.34 million tonnes, 40 percent more than in 1995/96 when yields were adversely affected by cool weather. Long grain production is forecast to be 260,000 tonnes.
